questions.text: A woman has 2 children named Ram and Shyam. One day, Shyam had measles with fever and rash. After 4 days, Ram developed the same symptoms. He was reported to the sub centre. Which of the following is not correct? A Shyam is the primary case B Ram is the index case C Ram got the infection from Shyam D If mother had reported when Shyam got the infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In epidemiology, the index case is the first case of a disease that comes to the attention of the public health authorities or healthcare providers. The primary case is the first case in a population or a study. In this scenario, Shyam was the first child to develop measles symptoms. However, his illness was not initially reported to the sub-centre. It was only when Ram developed symptoms that the case was reported. Therefore, Ram is the index case because his illness led to the report and the initiation of public health action. Shyam, having been the first infected individual in the family, is the primary case.

choices.text: It should not be given after 7 days
It has to be given in MAX amount at the deltoid
If human IG is not present, then give equine IG

questions.text: Rabies immunoglobulin false is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This statement is false because Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) should not be given in the deltoid muscle in its entirety. The primary purpose of RIG is to provide immediate, passive immunity at the site of the bite wound. Therefore, as much of the calculated dose as anatomically feasible should be infiltrated around and into the bite wound(s). Any remaining volume, if the wound site is insufficient to hold the entire dose, should then be administered intramuscularly (IM) at a site distant from the vaccination site (e.g., gluteal region, or anterolateral thigh in young children), but never in the deltoid if that is also the site planned for the rabies vaccine. The deltoid is the preferred site for rabies vaccine administration, and giving RIG in the same muscle can interfere with the immune response to the vaccine.

questions.text: Air quality Index in Delhi on occasion of Diwali on 23 November was 470. The assessment will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

According to the Air Quality Index (AQI) categories used in India by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) and SAFAR (System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting And Research), an AQI value of 401 to 500 falls under the "Severe" category. An AQI of 470 is squarely within this range. The "Severe" category indicates that the air pollution levels are extremely high and can cause respiratory illness on prolonged exposure. The effect may be more pronounced in people with lung and heart diseases, and even healthy people are significantly affected.

choices.text: Collect using paper/ cardboard and put in water tube/ bucket
Collect using your hand and discard
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: Mercury spill from sphygmomanometer question asked. What will u do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is the most appropriate and safe method for cleaning up a small mercury spill, such as from a broken sphygmomanometer. Mercury is a heavy liquid that forms small beads. Using a stiff piece of paper or cardboard allows you to carefully push these beads together and scoop them up without direct contact. Placing the collected mercury in a water-filled tube or bucket is crucial because water will help to minimize the evaporation of mercury, which releases toxic mercury vapor into the air. The container should then be sealed and clearly labeled for proper hazardous waste disposal. This method prioritizes minimizing human exposure to mercury vapor and preventing environmental contamination.

questions.text: All of the following increases Confidence interval except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increasing the sample size decreases the width of the confidence interval, rather than increasing it. This is because a larger sample size generally leads to a more precise estimate of the population parameter. As the sample size (n) increases, the standard error of the mean (or proportion) decreases. The formula for a confidence interval often involves the standard error in the denominator (e.g., SE=σ/ n ). A smaller standard error means a narrower interval, indicating greater precision in our estimate. Therefore, if we want to increase the precision of our estimate (i.e., make the confidence interval narrower), we should increase the sample size.

questions.text: Life span of Japanese women is 84.3 years. As Japanese have longest life expectancy, their life expectancy statistics are used as a standard for measuring premature death in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DALY stands for Disability-Adjusted Life Year. It is a measure of overall disease burden, expressed as the number of years lost due to ill-health, disability, or early death. One DALY represents the loss of one year of "healthy" life. The DALY calculation involves two main components:

  • Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality: This is calculated by subtracting the age at death from a standard life expectancy.
  • Years Lived with Disability (YLD) due to time lived in states of less than full health.

For the calculation of YLL, a theoretical maximum or ideal life expectancy is used as a standard. Historically, and even in current methodologies for global burden of disease studies, the highest observed or projected life expectancy (often from populations like Japanese women due to their consistent longevity) is used as this standard. This allows for a consistent comparison of premature death across different populations, measuring the "gap" from an ideal health state. Therefore, the long life expectancy of Japanese women serves as a benchmark for calculating the years of life lost due to premature death in DALYs.

choices.text: Green tea consumption increases risk of DM
Green tea consumption decreases risk of DM
Green tea consumption has no effect on the risk of DM

questions.text: A cohort study is undertaken to study association between green tea intake and DM. RR was found to be 0.85. Which is the following is correct regarding association between green tea and DM?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In a cohort study, the Relative Risk (RR) is a measure of the association between an exposure (green tea intake) and an outcome (Diabetes Mellitus - DM). It is calculated as the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group divided by the incidence of the outcome in the unexposed group.

  • RR = 1: Indicates no association between the exposure and the outcome. The risk of the outcome is the same in both exposed and unexposed groups.
  • RR > 1: Indicates an increased risk of the outcome in the exposed group. The exposure is a risk factor.
  • RR < 1: Indicates a decreased risk (or a protective effect) of the outcome in the exposed group. The exposure is a protective factor.

In this scenario, the Relative Risk (RR) is given as 0.85. Since 0.85 is less than 1, it indicates that individuals who consume green tea have a lower risk of developing Diabetes Mellitus compared to those who do not. Specifically, the risk of DM in green tea consumers is 85% of the risk in non-consumers, or conversely, there is a 15% reduction in risk (1 - 0.85 = 0.15). Therefore, green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM.

questions.text: As a trauma patient is brought to an emergency, there is blood spill on the floor. Which disinfectant would you use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sodium hypochlorite (commonly known as bleach) is the disinfectant of choice for decontaminating surfaces contaminated with blood or other bodily fluids, especially in a healthcare setting like an emergency room. It is a powerful oxidizing agent that is effective against a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses (like HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C, which are bloodborne pathogens), and fungi. For blood spills, a freshly prepared solution of 0.5% to 1% sodium hypochlorite is typically recommended. Its broad-spectrum efficacy and relatively low cost make it ideal for such critical cleaning situations to prevent the spread of infections.

questions.text: For analysis of functioning of a health centre with respect to evaluation, which of the following is the most important form assessing clinical management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

When analyzing the functioning of a health center with respect to the evaluation of clinical management, the process component is the most crucial. Process evaluation focuses on how healthcare services are delivered. It examines the activities, procedures, and interactions that occur during the provision of care. This includes assessing:

  • Adherence to clinical guidelines and protocols: Are healthcare professionals following established best practices for diagnosis, treatment, and patient care?
  • Quality of interactions between staff and patients: Is communication clear, empathetic, and patient-centered?
  • Timeliness of care: Are patients receiving interventions when they need them?
  • Appropriateness of investigations and treatments: Are the right tests being ordered and the most effective treatments being administered?
  • Coordination of care: How well do different departments or levels of care integrate to provide seamless service?

By evaluating the process, one can directly determine if clinical management is being performed effectively and efficiently. This provides actionable insights into areas for improvement in the delivery of care.

questions.text: WHO STEP wise approach includes all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The WHO STEPwise approach to Surveillance (STEPS) is a standardized method for collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data on key noncommunicable disease (NCD) risk factors. It is designed to help countries monitor NCD trends and inform public health policies. The STEPS approach focuses on three levels or "steps" of risk factor assessment:

  • Step 1: Questionnaire-based assessment (Behavioral): This step involves collecting self-reported information through a questionnaire on behavioral risk factors. These include tobacco use, alcohol consumption, unhealthy diet, and physical inactivity. These are often referred to as "behavioral" risk factors.

  • Step 2: Physical measurements (Physical): This step involves taking simple physical measurements. These typically include height, weight (to calculate BMI), waist circumference, and blood pressure. These are direct "physical" measurements.

  • Step 3: Biochemical measurements (Biochemical or Biological): This step involves collecting biological samples (e.g., blood or urine) for biochemical analysis. This is used to measure risk factors like raised blood glucose, abnormal blood lipids (cholesterol), and sometimes sodium levels. These are "biological" or "biochemical" measurements.

"Therapeutic" refers to treatment or therapy for diseases. The WHO STEPS approach is a surveillance tool aimed at collecting data on risk factors, not on the therapeutic management or treatment of existing diseases. While the data collected can inform therapeutic strategies and public health interventions, therapeutic actions themselves are not a component of the data collection methodology of the STEPS approach.

choices.text: Where SDH or DH is not present

questions.text: Criteria for establishing Urban CHC to ensure facilities:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) in India outlines the standards for Urban Community Health Centres (UCHCs). While the typical Urban CHC is generally a 30-50 bedded facility, in metro cities and large urban areas with a population exceeding 5 lakhs, the Urban CHC can be upgraded to a 100-bedded hospital. This is to cater to the higher population density and greater healthcare needs of these large cities, ensuring a comprehensive range of secondary care services and facilities are available. This specific criterion directly addresses the provision of facilities tailored to the scale of large urban populations.

questions.text: Broken glass vaccine vials at the vaccination centre are supposed to be disposed in which container:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

According to the Biomedical Waste Management Rules in India, broken or discarded glass including vaccine vials (cytotoxic or non-cytotoxic) are classified under "Glassware." These items are to be collected in a blue puncture-proof container. This specific container type is designated for glassware to prevent injuries from broken glass and to ensure safe handling and disposal of these types of waste, which may or may not be contaminated.

questions.text: Green colour on triage signifies:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In a mass casualty incident or disaster triage system (such as START - Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment), the color green is used to designate "minor" or "walking wounded" patients, often referred to as ambulatory patients. These are individuals with injuries that are not immediately life-threatening and who can walk and care for themselves or move to a designated casualty collection point. They will typically receive medical attention after patients in higher priority categories (red and yellow). The green tag signifies that they are stable enough to wait for treatment.

questions.text: For applied nutrition program, seeds and manure supply under school health services has been done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

UNICEF (United Nations Children's Fund) was a key international organization involved in supporting the Applied Nutrition Programme (ANP) in India and other developing countries. UNICEF, along with other UN agencies like WHO and FAO, collaborated with national governments to initiate and implement this country-wide action. UNICEF's mandate is specifically focused on the well-being of children, and improving nutrition through school-based initiatives, including providing support for school gardens (which would involve seeds and manure supply), aligns directly with their objectives. Records indicate UNICEF's significant involvement in the ANP, particularly in the initial phases and expansion of the program, which included components related to food production and nutrition education in schools and communities.

questions.text: Point ‘C’ indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Point 'C' marks the transition from the "STAGE OF SUBCLINICAL DISEASE" to the "STAGE OF CLINICAL DISEASE." The defining characteristic of the clinical stage of a disease is the appearance of signs and symptoms. During the subclinical stage (B), pathological changes are occurring within the body, but they are not yet severe enough to produce recognizable symptoms. Once the disease progresses to the point where symptoms become manifest, it enters the clinical stage. Therefore, point 'C' represents the onset of symptoms.

choices.text: In a population, if test shows more positive value in sensitivity, then there is lesser chance of people having disease

questions.text: Correct statement among following is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease. PPV is heavily influenced by the prevalence of the disease in the population being tested.

  • If the prevalence of the disease is high in a population, a positive test result is more likely to be a true positive, leading to a higher PPV.
  • Conversely, if the prevalence is low, even a highly sensitive and specific test can yield a lower PPV because there are fewer true positives and a relatively higher proportion of false positives.

This is a fundamental concept in diagnostic testing: the utility of a positive test result in predicting the presence of a disease is directly tied to how common that disease is in the group being tested.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a PHC. 50 patient’s requiring anti-hypertensive are being transferred to your PHC from periphery. 40 people need amlodipine )5 mg PO). 10 people have C/ I to use of amlodipine so those people have to be started with lisinopril (10 mg PO). Drugs comes to PHC once a month. How many drugs will you order combined and what will be reorder factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Let's break down the calculation for each drug and then combine them, along with determining the reorder factor.

1. Calculate Amlodipine Requirement:

Number of patients needing Amlodipine = 40
Dosage: 1 tablet per day (assuming 5mg PO is a once-daily dose, which is common for maintenance antihypertensives)
Tablets needed per patient per month (30 days) = 1 tablet/day * 30 days = 30 tablets
Total Amlodipine needed for 40 patients per month = 40 patients * 30 tablets/patient = 1200 tablets
2. Calculate Lisinopril Requirement:

Number of patients needing Lisinopril = 10
Dosage: 1 tablet per day (assuming 10mg PO is a once-daily dose, which is common for maintenance antihypertensives)
Tablets needed per patient per month (30 days) = 1 tablet/day * 30 days = 30 tablets
Total Lisinopril needed for 10 patients per month = 10 patients * 30 tablets/patient = 300 tablets
3. Total Drugs Needed Per Month:

Total Amlodipine + Total Lisinopril = 1200 + 300 = 1500 tablets per month.
4. Determine Reorder Factor:

Drugs come to the PHC once a month. This implies a monthly supply cycle.
The reorder factor (or safety stock factor) is often used to ensure there's enough supply to cover lead time for ordering and unexpected fluctuations in demand, typically aiming for 2-3 months of stock.
Given the options, a reorder factor of 2 or 3 is suggested. Let's test the options.
If the reorder factor is 2: Total order = 1500 tablets/month * 2 months = 3000 tablets.
If the reorder factor is 3: Total order = 1500 tablets/month * 3 months = 4500 tablets.
5. Match with Options:

Option D provides "3000, 2". This matches our calculation for a reorder factor of 2.
Therefore, you will order 3000 tablets combined (1200 Amlodipine + 300 Lisinopril for 2 months' supply each) and the reorder factor used is 2. This means ordering a quantity that would last for two months to ensure continuous supply until the next delivery.

questions.text: Global hunger index what is not included?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a comprehensive tool that measures and tracks hunger at global, regional, and national levels. It combines four component indicators to reflect the multifaceted nature of hunger. These four indicators are:

  1. Undernourishment (proportion of undernourished in the population): This reflects the share of the population whose caloric intake is insufficient.
  2. Child Wasting (proportion of children under the age of five who are wasted): This indicates acute undernutrition.
  3. Child Stunting (proportion of children under the age of five who are stunted): This indicates chronic undernutrition.
  4. Child Mortality (mortality rate of children under the age of five): This reflects in part the fatal synergy of inadequate nutrition and unhealthy environments.

The GHI specifically uses Child Mortality (under 5 mortality rate) as one of its components, not the narrower Infant Mortality Rate (deaths of children under one year of age). While infant mortality contributes to child mortality, the GHI indicator is the broader under-5 mortality rate. Therefore, Infant Mortality Rate as a standalone, distinct indicator is not directly included in the GHI's four components.

choices.text: Child is healthy, no advice required further
Child moderately undernourished (MAM), mother given advice
Child severely malnourished (SAM), mother given advice
Child severely malnourished (SAM), referral to nutritional rehabilitation centre (NRC)

questions.text: A 16 months old child has weight 8 kg. Look at the chart given below; best management will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Based on the provided WHO growth chart for girls, plotting the point for a 16-month-old child with a weight of 8 kg shows that the point falls within the light orange band. This band indicates Moderately Acute Malnutrition (MAM).

The appropriate management for Moderately Acute Malnutrition (MAM) at the primary healthcare level involves:

  • Nutritional counseling: Providing the mother or caregiver with essential advice on improved feeding practices, including dietary diversity, increased frequency of feeding, and appropriate portion sizes.
  • Hygiene promotion: Emphasizing good hygiene practices to prevent infections that can worsen nutritional status.
  • Monitoring and follow-up: Regular monitoring of the child's weight gain and overall health progress at subsequent visits to the health center.
  • In some programs, supplementary feeding (e.g., ready-to-use supplementary food or food rations) may also be provided for MAM cases, but nutritional counseling and follow-up are fundamental.

This approach aims to prevent further deterioration of the child's nutritional status and promote recovery within the community setting without requiring inpatient hospitalization unless complications arise.

choices.text: History of similar events in past

questions.text: Patient from Chhattisgarh complaints of Spasticity and pure motor palsy. What history to ask?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Given that the patient is from Chhattisgarh and presents with spasticity and pure motor palsy, the most crucial history to ask is about food intake. This is because these symptoms are highly suggestive of lathyrism, a neurological disorder caused by prolonged consumption of Lathyrus sativus (grass pea or khesari dal) containing a neurotoxin called ODAP ( β−N-oxalyl-L-α,β-diaminopropionic acid). Lathyrism is endemic in certain parts of India, including Chhattisgarh, especially during periods of drought or food scarcity when the grass pea becomes a staple diet. The clinical presentation of lathyrism typically involves spastic paraparesis, leading to a characteristic stiff-legged gait, and can progress to pure motor palsy. Therefore, inquiring about the consumption of khesari dal or other unusual dietary staples is critical for diagnosis.

choices.text: Weekly dose of 60 mg iron & 500 ug folic acid
Daily dose of 60 mg iron & 500 ug folic acid
Weekly dose of 100 mg iron & 500 ug folic acid
Daily dose of 100 mg iron & 500 ug folic acid

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Currently trivalent strain is used in India in OPV
Endemic countries are Pakistan, and Afghanistan
Type 2 strain gone from India in 1999, and Type 3 strain rarely seen in India
Residual paralysis in regard to polio seen in quadriceps femoris muscle

questions.text: Which is not true for polio vaccine ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A.	Currently trivalent strain is used in India in OPV: FALSE (now we use bOPV)

B.	Endemic countries are Pakistan, and Afghanistan: TRUE

C.	Type 2 strain gone from India in 1999, and Type 3 strain rarely seen in India: TRUE

D.	Residual paralysis in regard to polio seen in quadriceps femoris muscle: TRUE

choices.text: TB is not a part of IDSP
Flaccid paralysis is under sentinel surveillance

questions.text: IDSP false statement is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TB is part of IDSP IHIP

Explanation: The Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), now integrated into the Integrated Health Information Platform (IHIP) in India, aims to detect and respond to disease outbreaks quickly. HIV is indeed a disease that falls under surveillance by IDSP/IHIP, given its public health importance. Flaccid paralysis, particularly Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) often due to polio, is a key condition under sentinel surveillance, as it helps in tracking and eradicating polio. The P form is typically filled by a physician or other healthcare provider to report cases of specific diseases. The statement that TB is not a part of IDSP is false. Tuberculosis (TB) is a major public health concern in India and is actively monitored and reported under the IDSP/IHIP framework to track its incidence and control its spread.

questions.text: Global hunger index what is not included?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Infant mortality rate

questions.text: Air quality Index in Delhi on occasion of Diwali on 23 November was 407. The assessment will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: 5 cases of kaposis sarcoma was reported among homosexuals for the ﬁrst time. Which is the type of study done in them to help to formulate hypothesis –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Explanation: When a new or unusual cluster of cases of a disease, like the initial reports of Kaposi's sarcoma among homosexual men (which later led to the understanding of AIDS), is observed for the first time, a case series is the most appropriate type of study to start with. A case series describes the characteristics of a group of patients with a particular disease or condition. It's often the first step in formulating hypotheses about potential causes, risk factors, or associations, as it highlights patterns or unusual occurrences that warrant further investigation. A cross-sectional study looks at prevalence at a single point in time, a case-control study compares exposures in cases and controls, and a cohort study follows a group over time to observe outcomes. These latter study designs are typically used after a hypothesis has been generated, often from initial observations like those in a case series, to test specific associations.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 villages and number of typhoid carriers were computed and compared . This type of study is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation: The study described involves computing and comparing the number of typhoid carriers in three villages. This implies that data on the presence of typhoid carriers is collected at a specific point in time across these different populations or groups. This type of study, which assesses the prevalence of a condition (in this case, being a typhoid carrier) in a defined population at a single point in time, is characteristic of a cross-sectional study. Cross-sectional studies are useful for determining the prevalence of diseases or risk factors and for generating hypotheses, but they cannot establish causality. A case series describes individual cases, a case-control study compares exposures between cases and controls, and a cohort study follows groups over time to observe outcomes, none of which perfectly fit the description of simply "computing and comparing" numbers of carriers at a given moment across different villages.

questions.text: Matching is done to eliminate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Known confounders

Explanation: In epidemiological studies, matching is a technique used to control for confounding variables. It involves selecting study participants (e.g., controls in a case-control study or comparison groups in a cohort study) so that they are similar to the cases or exposed group with respect to certain characteristics that are known or suspected confounders. By matching on these variables (e.g., age, sex, smoking status), the researcher aims to ensure that the groups being compared are similar for those specific factors, thereby eliminating or reducing their confounding effect on the observed association between the exposure and the outcome. Matching is effective in controlling for known confounders because the researcher specifically chooses which variables to match on. It does not directly eliminate the effects of unknown confounders, as those are, by definition, not recognized or measured.

questions.text: Study design preferred for rare disease :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Explanation: For rare diseases, a case-control study is the most preferred and efficient study design. In a case-control study, researchers identify individuals who already have the rare disease (cases) and then compare them to a group of individuals who do not have the disease but are similar in other relevant characteristics (controls). The past exposures of both groups are then retrospectively investigated to determine if there's an association with the disease. This approach is efficient for rare diseases because it avoids the need to follow a very large population for a long time to observe a sufficient number of disease cases, which would be necessary for a cohort study. Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are primarily used for evaluating interventions and are generally not suitable for studying the etiology of rare diseases due to ethical and practical limitations. Cohort studies are prospective and require following a large group of individuals over time, which would be impractical and extremely expensive if the outcome (the rare disease) is infrequent.

questions.text: Recall bias can be eliminated by :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prospective studies

Explanation: Recall bias occurs when there are systematic differences in the way information about past exposures or events is remembered or reported by study participants. This type of bias is particularly common in retrospective studies (like case-control studies) where participants are asked to recall exposures from the past. Individuals with a disease (cases) might recall past exposures more accurately or with more detail than healthy individuals (controls), or vice-versa, leading to a spurious association. Prospective studies are designed to eliminate or significantly reduce recall bias because exposure information is collected before the disease outcome occurs. In a prospective study (e.g., a cohort study), participants are followed over time, and data on exposures are gathered at the beginning of the study or as they occur, before the development of the outcome. This ensures that the recall of exposure is not influenced by the knowledge of the disease status. While using questionnaires and proper selection of controls are important for data collection and controlling other biases, they do not inherently eliminate recall bias; in fact, questionnaires can be a source of it if they rely on retrospective recall.

questions.text: Attrition bias is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Explanation: Attrition bias, also known as loss to follow-up bias, occurs in studies where participants drop out of the study before it is completed, and these dropouts are not random but related to both the exposure and the outcome. This differential loss of participants can lead to a skewed sample and inaccurate results. Attrition bias is primarily a concern in cohort studies and randomized controlled trials (which are a type of prospective cohort study) because these designs involve following participants over a period of time. Over this follow-up period, some participants may be lost to follow-up due to various reasons (e.g., moving, death, unwillingness to continue). If the reasons for attrition are related to the exposure or outcome, it can introduce bias. Case-control and cross-sectional studies are typically conducted at a single point in time or retrospectively, and while they can suffer from other forms of bias, attrition bias in the sense of loss to follow-up is not their primary concern.

questions.text: Multiples outcomes because of exposure to smoking can be studied by :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Cohort study

Explanation: To study multiple outcomes resulting from a single exposure, a cohort study is the most suitable epidemiological design. In a cohort study, a group of individuals (the cohort) is identified based on their exposure status (e.g., smokers versus non-smokers). These individuals are then followed prospectively over time to observe the development of various diseases or health outcomes. Since the exposure (smoking) is determined at the outset, researchers can track all subsequent health events that occur in both exposed and unexposed groups. This allows for the investigation of multiple potential outcomes (e.g., lung cancer, heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, stroke) related to that single exposure. Other study designs are less appropriate: Ecological studies look at population-level data and cannot link exposure to individual outcomes. Case-control studies start with the outcome and look backward at exposure, making them efficient for single outcomes but less so for multiple. Crossover RCTs are interventional studies where participants receive different treatments sequentially, not ideal for observing multiple natural outcomes from a single exposure like smoking.

questions.text: Randomization in RCTs can increase:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: Randomization in Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) is a cornerstone of this study design because it aims to ensure that the groups being compared (e.g., treatment vs. control) are similar in all characteristics, both known and unknown, except for the intervention being studied. By randomly assigning participants to groups, confounding variables are distributed evenly across the groups, minimizing the chance that observed differences in outcomes are due to these other factors rather than the intervention itself. This critical process directly contributes to enhancing the internal validity of the study. Internal validity refers to the extent to which a study establishes a trustworthy cause-and-effect relationship between the exposure and the outcome, meaning that the observed effect is truly due to the intervention and not to extraneous factors. While a well-designed RCT can also contribute to external validity (generalizability) if the study population is representative, randomization's primary and most direct impact is on strengthening internal validity. Sensitivity and specificity are terms related to diagnostic tests, not study design validity.

questions.text: Funnel plot is used to detect :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Publication bias

Explanation: A funnel plot is a graphical tool primarily used in meta-analyses to visually assess for the presence of publication bias. Publication bias occurs when the likelihood of a study being published is influenced by the significance or direction of its results (e.g., studies with statistically significant positive findings are more likely to be published than those with null or negative findings). In a funnel plot, the effect size of individual studies is plotted against a measure of their precision (e.g., standard error or sample size). In the absence of bias, the plot should resemble a symmetrical inverted funnel, with larger, more precise studies clustered at the top and smaller, less precise studies spread out more widely at the bottom. An asymmetrical or skewed funnel plot suggests the presence of publication bias, where smaller studies with non-significant results may be missing. While selection bias and recall bias are important considerations in individual studies, the funnel plot is specifically designed to detect publication bias across a collection of studies in a systematic review or meta-analysis.

questions.text: Diagnostic power of exclusion :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

NPV

Explanation: The "diagnostic power of exclusion" refers to the ability of a test to rule out a disease when the test result is negative. This concept is directly measured by the Negative Predictive Value (NPV). NPV is the probability that a person who tests negative for a disease actually does not have the disease. A high NPV means that a negative test result is very reliable for ruling out the condition.

questions.text: If prevalence increases, PPV:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: The Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the probability that a person who tests positive for a disease actually has the disease. It is highly influenced by the prevalence of the disease in the population being tested. If the prevalence of a disease increases, it means that the disease is more common in that population. When a test yields a positive result in a population with higher prevalence, there's a greater likelihood that this positive result truly reflects the presence of the disease, simply because there are more true cases in that population. Conversely, in a population with low prevalence, even a highly specific test can yield many false positives, leading to a lower PPV. Therefore, if prevalence increases, the PPV of a diagnostic test increases.

questions.text: Formula for positive likelihood ratio :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: The positive likelihood ratio (LR+) is a measure used in diagnostic testing to assess how much the odds of having a disease increase when a diagnostic test result is positive. It combines the sensitivity and specificity of a test into a single value.

choices.text: True positives rates and true negatives rates
True positives rates and test positives rates
True positives rates and false positives rate
True positives rate and test negatives rate

questions.text: ROC curve is a plot drawn between :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: A Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve is a graphical plot that illustrates the diagnostic ability of a binary classifier system as its discrimination threshold is varied. It is created by plotting the True Positive Rate (Sensitivity) on the Y-axis against the False Positive Rate (1 - Specificity) on the X-axis at various threshold settings. The curve shows the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity for different possible cut-off points of a diagnostic test. The closer the curve is to the top-left corner, the better the diagnostic performance of the test. The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a common metric used to quantify the overall diagnostic accuracy of a test.

questions.text: Time between earliest point of detection and usual time of diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: The "time between the earliest point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis" refers to the period by which a disease can be diagnosed earlier through screening compared to when it would typically be diagnosed based on symptoms or routine clinical practice. This concept is known as lead time. Lead time is a crucial consideration in evaluating the effectiveness of screening programs, as it represents the potential benefit of earlier diagnosis, which might lead to earlier intervention and improved outcomes.

questions.text: Out of 100 students, starting from 4th every 10th is selected. This sampling is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: The sampling method described, where a starting point is chosen randomly (e.g., 4th student) and then every 'k'th element (e.g., every 10th student) is selected from a list or sequence, is known as systematic random sampling. This method is a type of probability sampling where the first element is selected randomly from a specified interval, and then subsequent elements are selected at fixed intervals. It's considered random because every element has an equal chance of being selected based on the initial random start, and it's systematic due to the fixed interval.

questions.text: All are non parametric tests except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not rely on assumptions about the shape or parameters of the population distribution (e.g., normality). They are often used when data are ordinal, nominal, or when the assumptions for parametric tests are violated

Paired t-test is a parametric test used to compare the means of two related groups (e.g., before-and-after measurements on the same subjects). It assumes that the differences between the paired observations are normally distributed.

questions.text: Corelation coeﬃcient can indicate strength of relationship between :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A correlation coefficient (like Pearson's r) measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two quantitative (numerical) variables.

Weight and BP (Blood Pressure): Both weight and blood pressure are quantitative variables. As weight increases, blood pressure often tends to increase in a linear fashion. Therefore, a correlation coefficient can effectively indicate the strength of this linear relationship.
